comments.commentBody: Rather than wait out the 10yrs before you can retire, please look into some options to get support to help you maintain a healthy weight. Losing weight is much easier than keeping it off. If you go to WW, stay with them after you lose the weight. Support for maintenance is everything, and I'm speaking from experience. Best of luck!

I agree with Angela in San Jose...I saw lots of other people seem to benefit from Overeaters Anonymous but I went every week for several years and if anything only gained more weight during that time.  I tried Weight Watchers in the past but might be up for trying it again.  The only thing that I think will really cure my food addiction is...retirement.  My biggest eating issues are around my job.  However, it will be at least another ten years before I can leave it behind.
Reminds me of a less than PC folk tale I heard on a voyage; 'Woe is me!*, lamented the Gypsy. *I was teaching my horse not to eat, but just when it had learned the trick, it up and dies on me!'

At firs, cutting back on favorite foods can be very distressing. However, the longer one avoids (for example) ice-cream, the less one wants ice-cream, the less ice-cream it takes to have a satisfying experience, and the easier it is to avoid ice-cream altogether for very long periods of time.

The first two years are the hardest. Thereafter, everything gets much easier.

This is interesting.  I do not think that I am addicted to food in the sense that it's meant in this setting, and my score indicated this.  However, for a couple questions I wasn't sure how to answer.  I am not overweight and I have a very low body fat percentage.  I play a sport professionally, and my efforts are mostly towards trying to eat more.  However, my need to eat sometimes isn't tied to true hunger, and sometimes family members get upset having to prepare full meals.  I think that being addicted to food is a really interesting concept since everyone is "addicted" to food.  If you don't eat, you die.  As was already said, if over eathing is an issue, it's not so simple as don't eat.  You can't just completely give up food.  I think of all the addictions, it must be awful to want something that you can only have a bit of.

I watched chemotherapy burn out my mother-in-law's veins burn out in the 1980's when she fought breast cancer. I was diagnosed with Stage IIIc ovarian cancer last year and the Cleveland Clinic recommended an implanted port before starting chemotherapy. Some of the chemotherapy drugs can be very caustic on small veins. They explained all of the benefits and risks and I immediately agreed.

After my initial debulking surgery, I was hospitalized 4 times in one year with additional complications and follow up surgery. Each time the hospital accessed the port once and left in a pigtail covered by special tape for the whole stay. The port works both ways - for blood draw and injecting fluids, chemotherapy and medications. They even used the port to inject radioactive glucose for my PET scan. The only time I've been stuck by a needle in my arm since my ovarian cancer diagnosis has been for surgical anesthesia. My platelet count went very low during chemotherapy treatment but, with a port, I never had to worry about insufficient blood clotting after port access.

Infection is a constant worry for immunologically suppressed. I think being stuck once, reliably, in a port beats being repeated stuck in the arm and hand and wrist when the nurses have to go vein hunting.

I agree it is hard for laypeople to make medical decisions about their treatment. Thank you for sharing your thought process with us about one decision on a very long treatment road of a difficult disease.
Good luck and congrats on the port! I had mine removed recently, which was also a short procedure.  I thought it was a huge help having it.
Ms Gubar, i'm an oncologist in seattle and i love your candor and thoughtfulness. I'm sending this to my entire team--as a great lesson in what autonomy means and how delicate it is to respect.

I'm pretty hard to stick, too. Each time I go in for a CT with contrast, or a PET scab, or fluids or just bloodwork, they always ask if I have a port, and I think they're a little sorry I don't! But I didn't need chemo, only radiation.

But I did resist a feeding tube, with my doctors' encouragement. In some places they are placed before treatment as a standard procedure, but we all felt that I would be able to get through without one. About halfway through, though, I asked for one, and for about a year it and I had a love-hate relationship. I was happy to learn that when it was no longer needed I could remove the thing myself. Empowering!

I think that the headline in this article, while attention-grabbing, is somewhat misleading. I think that it plays into many people's fascination of taking things to extremes (isn't that the American way)?

The key take-away, however, is still the notion of increased overall physical activity (along with careful monitoring of food intake). Indeed, "exercise" (that is, intense or vigorous physical activity) can only be sustained by most people for relatively short periods of time (1 hour, 3 or even 5 times a week isn't all that much in the grand scheme of things). Meanwhile, not only does one typically eat more in a misguided attempt to "replenish" from a hard work out, but overall activity drops as people typically try to recover from fatigue, soreness, or even injury.

What the article really wants to say is that, just like food intake, the "binge-and-purge" paradigm for physical activity doesn't work when it comes to weight loss, or even improving fitness. What does work is steadily increasing overall physical activity (along with careful monitoring of food intake) in a lifestyle sustainable fashion.

1)  Your clever post, preich, brings up an interesting point.  I treated patients, on staff, at a nationally ranked medical establishment in NE Ohio for six years.  I am not an MD, so of course, my opinion may mean nothing to you medically savy posters.  During that time it was recommended that I get a liver biopsy – one that would not change or initiate any treatment for an under control condition, but the MD thought it might be interesting.  I declined.  Liver biopsies are not without risk – years later a friend sat on a wrongful death jury for some patient who died following their liver biopsy - which I hope was performed for a better reason than ‘interest’.  Later, it was suggested to me to have a an invasive sinus surgery for a troublesome condition (watering eyes) that, according to the doctor, almost never clears up on its own.  Rather than have tubes implanted or holes drilled in my face next to my eye, I opted to see if it would clear up on its own – it did.  However, they finally ‘got me’ on a cystoscopy that a doc insisted was necessary and routine – had I declined, my life would look very different today.  However, one cystoscopy acquired infection later, and 5 days of cipro (which I argued with the prescribing doctor repeatedly about due to something I heard about a warning for tendon damage) and my body was destroyed and my ability to work with my hands & practice my profession .  . . gone.  - continued in 2)

I am mystified. No one has been saying anything against those that actually create something. No one is complaining about Elon Musk or Bill Gates or Steve Jobs. We are complaining about Mittens, Jamie Dimon and those who think that financial manipulations make our country great. And we are complaining that while the productivity of American workers has been steadily increasing, their wages have stagnated.

We understand the greatness of American creativity, and it should be rewarded. But we don't understand how the wealthy could be so greedy. Lower their tax rates and they get greedier. Elon Musk is not calibrating his creativity to the tax code. He is a real creator. Bill Gates and Steve Jobs did not make their mark based on tax codes.

We are for success. We are for creativity. We are for all boats rising together. And Mittens is clearly not. He has demonstrated a callousness that is mind boggling, flip-flops on positions that defy belief, and foolishness pandering to the right wing nuts and greedy financiers.

And we haven't even touched on the demented need of Mittens and the right to control our sexual behavior, to deny women the full spectrum of health services they require.

The growing income inequality has everything to do with corporations sacrificing the long term good for short term profits in order to concentrate the wealth at the top of the management tree. Even Henry Ford recognized the folly of this position.

AND...

Romney has shown us nothing but lies, shiftiness, foreign policy ineptitude and secret plans. The plans remind me of his tax returns. "Just trust me." How is this manipulator going to do anything? He does not have the backbone to stand up to the Todd Akins of this world. It is truly pathetic.

David, many thanks, you have recovered your perspective, and I very much admire this return to the forward looking culture which has always characterized the US. Not everyone can be successful, for competition, that wonderful unpredictable leveler sorts out the winners and the losers, aided by changing trends in the marketplace, notably recently off shoring; not the government nor the winners and losers lottery conducted by any politician.

The personal characteristics of Mr Musk are of little or no interest to me and his accomplishments are. Historically the highly successful are not the Saturday night poker game pals nor the beer in the bar or on the front porch buddies. That he has already done as much as he has is astounding and indicative as to how this phenomenal country affords like minded people the opportunity to excel. That is precisely what our country needs to understand as the the choices for the leadership of our country are considered and then debated over the period culminating on November 6th.

The seriousness of the choice to be made is critical to the current 315 million population, for among that number there are other young people as brilliant and potentially successful as Mr Musk. Or there are among the millions waiting patiently in line to enter the US legally, numbers of people like Mr Musk. The voters will decide freely whether our country follows the path of success of free enterprise or opt for mediocrity as the new normal. Critical choice.

It's really not the doctors fault hearing there's been trouble with the drug (having read what this drug is supposed to do) if you yourself haven't SEEN first hand what it actually DOES! I've been having pain in my side for over a month and after several online searches since, I see why the doctors have been so confused with my symptoms. I was according to 4 doctors treated in the right way. It wasn't my doctors fault that the medicine is worse than the actual problem. The joint pain isn't correctly listed in the side effects! Who KNEW this could still be hurting me 19 days later????? It says "may cause joint pain". Easy to miss, cause there are like a THOUSAND possible side effects, we all just skim over, going OK... MAYBE and that's like so small and you think, it'll only last a minute? Turns out NO!! It would be better to get a rash you could treat! This pain has been long lasting and I'm a very healthy 35 yr old woman, 5'1" and 110 with clothes and shoes. I read the insert, but I didn't do this to myself. To say someone who reads the possible side effects, gave themselves one is plain STUPID!! Who doesn't read the papers with their meds?? DOCTORS??? (Not aiming this at you) but the doctors before you who accused patients of reading and then being unfortunate enough to suffer a side effect they'd read. Just DUMB to use that as an excuse to dismiss an adverse reaction.

Other than that, I believe the only other Repugnant "plan" is to hope that people just die off sooner. After all, why shouldn't the Mittens and friends be able to keep ALL of their money? Why should they forego that third or fourth house, or maybe an additional car elevator just to take care of some old people?

My home town is fortunate to many have many well off people who contribute money, time and talents to the institutions that help all kinds of people, the arts, health care, education and the many ithings that make our wonderful bi-cultural community richer for everyone.

They aren't as rich as Romney, probably don't especially want to be, but contribute so much more in many ways and have a lot more fun doing it.
